11:08 am
IK11:09am

Welcome to the last day of May, the month not the UK PM ahead of next week's election. On the subject of UK politics I had the surreal experience of being in a hotel room in Berlin last night wifi-ing into my TV at home and seeing the leader of the opposition Jeremy Corbyn presenting a pot of homemade jam to the interviewer on the show he was on. He also boasted about his love of his allotment. Before I get too critical my recent attempt at making homemade hummus was a disaster and I should add that in a small herb garden we have outside our kitchen, this year's basil has just died over the weekend in spite of much attempted love and affection. The herb garden cost us a fortune to install and was meant to be a lasting monument to our wedding and one that would provide us with many good harvests over the years ahead and remind us of our happy day. So far we've got the equivalent of about 5 pots of herbs out of it in nearly 4 years. They would have cost us about 5 pounds in the supermarket. Like my basil, markets are wilting slightly at the moment. There's nothing sinister around but it does feel like there is a slight loss of confidence as data momentum is stalling a touch and politics continues to be unpredictable.

IK11:09am

Staying in the UK there's been a bit of a shock poll overnight from YouGov/ Times that shows that the Conservative Party could lose 20 seats in next week’s election and with it the party’s current slim majority. The poll showed that the Conservative Party is on track to take 310 seats (versus 330 seats currently) with 326 seats needed for a majority while Labour may win 257 seats, up from 229. That central estimate therefore implies a hung parliament. The poll is YouGov’s first constituency-by-constituency estimate however it appears that the model allows for big variations and a large margin of error with it also suggesting that the Conservatives could take home as many as 345 seats and as few as 274. The model supposedly draws upon 50,000 respondents quizzed over the course of a week. Notwithstanding the complexity of the polling methodology and some of the large variations, the headlines saw Sterling immediately tumble around -0.50% and down to as low as $1.279, although it has bounced back a bit since and currently sits at -0.35%.

KS11:10am

Here's the poll if you haven't seen (courtesy of The Times)

11:10 am
KS11:10am

KS11:11am

And some grey from Jim's colleagues Mark Wall and Oliver Harvey

KS11:11am

Scenario 1: Majority < 50, but > current 17 – PM May is likely to cling onto power, but without the majority needed to conduct negotiations effectively. The influence of hard Brexit Conservative MPs over looming issues such as the divorce bill would be large and the chances of reaching a deal with the EU correspondingly low. The purpose of an early general election would have been negated, and significant economic weakness and/or market pressure would once again be required to secure a transitional deal, or the UK would crash out of the EU in March 2019.

11:11 am
KS11:11am

Scenario 2: Majority < current 17 – May’s support within the Conservative Party is highly contingent on electoral success. The right of the party (already unhappy at her unopposed victory in the leadership contest last year) would likely launch a challenge if the Prime Minister did not herself resign. A hard Brexit candidate would have a good chance of winning a leadership election. In the event May stayed on for continuity reasons, her political authority would be severely undermined and the same political constraints would apply as in scenario 1.

KS11:11am

Scenario 3: Loss of majority – if the Conservative party win less than 320 seats, there would be little prospect of remaining in government, even after taking account of support from the Democratic Unionist Party. The most likely alternative would be a ‘progressive alliance,’ made up of Labour, the Liberal Democrats and the SNP. This would be extremely unstable, with SNP and Liberal support, formal or otherwise, conditional on a number of compromises. The overall stance towards Brexit would be softer, but delivery risks would be large. It would take time to formulate a common negotiating position out of differing party stances (a second referendum proposed by the Liberal Democrats, an independence referendum before Brexit for the SNP). With early progress needed in talks, this is not a luxury the UK enjoys.

KS11:11am

Scenario 4: Labour Party victory – the most unlikely scenario at this stage. Labour Party policy towards Brexit is softer (to secure the benefits of Single Market Access and a more open immigration policy than the Conservatives), but detail is thin and delivery remains the largest obstacle as above. It would also be questionable to what extent a softer Brexit policy would be outweighed by less market friendly policies such as rises to corporation tax and higher public spending.

11:11 am
KS11:11am

In sum, none of the alternatives are market-friendly. GBP vol remains subdued, with two week GBP/USD risk premia and outright vol way below other UK political event risks such as the May 2015 election, Brexit and Scottish independence referendum (fig 3). This suggests value in owning downside, particularly given our fundamentally-driven bearish outlook for the pound

IK11:18am

Our negative view on sterling has been challenged so far in 2017. Indeed, EUR/GBP has been stable since January, trading within a fairly tight range around 0.85, c. 15% lower than our long-standing 2017 forecast of 1.00. A number of factors are regularly invoked to explain this. First of all, the economy has been resilient despite the outcome of the EU referendum last year. This has allowed the BoE to moderate its easing bias and adopt a more neutral stance, especially as inflation is well above target. In addition, there have been few Brexitrelated triggers, which alongside short positioning may have supported sterling further. During the last few quarters, however, and in particular Q4, there has been an additional development, which has gone relatively unnoticed; a large improvement in the current account balance. Being at the heart of our bearish view on sterling, this inevitably raises the question: has currency depreciation already helped the UK current account to rebalance, therefore requiring no additional weakness? In what follows, we are taking a deep dive into the dynamics of the UK current account balance. We find that most of the improvement is due to the income balance, which is in turn driven mainly by global cyclical factors (global asset reflation) and not recent sterling weakness.

IK11:18am

This has important implications. First, sterling may depreciate less than we originally envisaged as long as the global cycle remains supportive. Secondly, however, this also means that sterling could depreciate significantly if global reflation dynamics fade. Thirdly, the sensitivity of the current account to changes in the currency is substantially smaller than we originally assumed. This implies more sterling damage for a given correction in the current account, other things equal. Lastly, Brexit risks only serve to skew currency risks heavily to the downside. Overall, our modal outlook for the global economy and the dynamics of the UK current account justify some moderation in the path and extent of projected sterling weakness. Accordingly, we now see EUR/GBP at 0.92 in end-17 and 0.97 at end-18 (from 1.00 for both years previously). The risks to these new forecasts, however, remain firmly skewed towards sterling downside.

Consumer sentiment strengthened marginally as spring came into full swing with the headline GfK Consumer Confidence Barometer printing -5 in May, after -7 in April. The 2pt increase was driven by an improvement in sentiment with regard to personal finances ahead and with regard to the intent to make a major purchase over the next twelve months. Resilient consumer confidence over the last few months comes against a background of rising inflation, the triggering of Article 50, and the impending election.

KS11:24am

The announcement

KS11:24am

The Minister for Finance of Ireland, Michael Noonan T.D. (the "Minister for Finance", or the "Selling Shareholder"), and AIB, Ireland's leading retail and commercial bank, today announce an intention to seek admission of the Company's ordinary shares ("Ordinary Shares") to the Official Lists of each of the Irish Stock Exchange and the FCA and to proceed with a secondary offering of Ordinary Shares by the Minister for Finance (combined the "IPO", or the "Offer").

The Irish State owns approximately 99.9% of AIB's Ordinary Shares having invested c.€20.8 billion in AIB since 2009, €6.6 billion of which has already been returned in capital, fees, dividends and coupons. The Government's policy has been to return its banking investments, including AIB, to private ownership over time in a manner which recoups the cost of the support for the benefit of the Irish public. Given AIB's strong financial performance and current market conditions, the Minister for Finance has decided that the timing is now right for the Irish State to commence this process.

KS11:26am

Irish Banks: AIB intention to float released this morning – (Analyst: Owen Callan)

News: The much-awaited AIB intention to float (ITF) has been announced by the Irish government, with the State seeking to sell approximately 25% of the ordinary shares it owns in AIB via a secondary offering. The bank is seeking admission of the company’s ordinary shares to the official lists of both the Irish Stock Exchange (ISE) and the FCA, and is also seeking admission to trading on the main markets of the ISE and the London Stock Exchange. The Offer is expected to take place in the coming weeks, with the publication of the Prospectus and announcement of the price range in mid-June. Investec Bank plc (Irish Branch) is acting as Co-Lead Manager on the AIB offer.

IK11:27am

This is some context from David Mackie at JP Morgan from last week

IK11:27am

According to the European Commission’s calculations, Ireland still has a structural deficit of 1.1% of GDP. This reflects the Commission’s assessment of the state of the Irish business cycle. With a judgment that the Irish economy has passed beyond full employment, the cyclically adjusted fiscal position is worse than the non-cyclically adjusted position (Table 2). Meanwhile, Ireland meets the debt rule. If the 2017 estimates for the primary position, nominal growth and borrowing costs were sustained, the Irish debt-to-GDP ratio would be around 20% in 20 years. The move in Ireland from a program country to fiscal high achiever over recent years is remarkable. Obviously, Ireland has benefitted from nominal GDP growth far in excess of anything seen elsewhere in the region, but according to the European Commission’s structural deficit estimates it has also engaged in a significant amount of fiscal tightening.

11:30 am
IK11:31am

High underwriting costs of IPOs were a “neglected aspect” in recent studies of the decline in the number of companies tapping the public equity markets over the past decade, according to the OECD, the Paris-based inter-governmental organisation that aims to foster economic growth. “High levels of fees and parallel pricing (akin to tacit collusion) appear to have increased,” said the OECD in its annual business and finance outlook report published on Tuesday.
The standard 7 per cent fee that investment banks charge for underwriting IPOs in the US have been criticised since the late 1990s. Little has changed in the past 20 years, with the OECD’s data showing that the median US underwriting fee was 7 per cent of total IPO proceeds every year between 2000 and 2016. While European IPOs have lower and more varied fees than their US counterparts, the OECD said that the “one-fee” model also persists in Japan at an even higher 8 per cent rate. As a result, the OECD estimates that European equity issuers have been paying around half of the fees of those paid by US and Japanese companies.

KS11:33am

11:33 am
KS11:33am

We are downgrading Worldpay to Equal Weight as we cannot find enough upside to warrant a price target increase and we have some concern regarding the organic growth trend. We calculate that underlying organic growth peaked at 9.6% in 1H15 and slowed to 6.3% in 2H16. We suspect that some is transitory due to the US, management turnover and the platform transition, but there is a risk that Worldpay could miss its organic growth target of 9-11% in FY17

KS11:34am

And their broad thesis

KS11:34am

Questions around growth: WPG has experienced many one-off net revenue impacts and we have made an attempt to exclude these, providing us with an underlying organic growth trend. This shows that the business slowed in each of the last three half years.

11:33 am
KS11:34am

What can it grow at? We calculate that its regional and category code mix is able to generate ~8-9% organic growth. Any deviation from this “base” growth needs to come from share gains, pricing or value chain expansion.

KS11:34am

Is 9-11% feasible? Given the above, we wonder if WPG is entering a next stage whereby it will temper its growth ambitions and increasingly focus on margin expansion. At the moment, it is guiding to 100bp annual margin expansion beyond 2018 and, if it is able to moderate OpEx growth, we calculate 150bp p.a. is feasible.

KS11:34am

M&A also an option: New US management has a clear mandate and the business is now stable. However, to turn this into a strategic asset for the group and support its global eCom strategy, investments are needed. As highlighted in prior reports, we are of the opinion that corporate development for the group is a more logical solution”

The company

KS11:40am

Despite a quiet fourth quarter in financial markets, IG's revenue in the period was higher than in the same quarter a year ago. The Company expects to report full year revenue around 7% higher than in the prior year

11:40 am
KS11:40am

And quick bit of grey from Shore Cap

KS11:40am

Revenue for the final quarter is said to be higher than in the same quarter last year (which was £119.5m) resulting in full year revenue up around 7%. This would imply full year revenue of c£488m (Shore : £496m. company-complied consensus £496m). Given the lack of market volatility in Q4, a key driver of client activity, we regard this as a relatively resilient outcome. Costs have been well controlled in H2, being flat on H1 compared to our forecast of a £10m increase. The reduction includes an unquantified rebate from the FSCS relating to prior years. We would also not be surprised if marketing spend moderated in H2 as IG have the ability to flex this line to match underlying market conditions, typically increasing it when volatility is higher. Overall this means full year PBT is expected to be ‘moderately ahead’ of last year’s £207.9m and therefore compares favourably with our current £206.1m forecast (consensus £209m), again a resilient result given market conditions.

IK11:40am

@peterc - autosubprime is in our highly organised running order for ML. Just hang on.

11:40 am
KS11:41am

IG’s previous quarter (3m to Feb ’17) also fell in this period of very low volatility (trading revenue of £117.4m was down 4% yoy and 12% sequentially on Q2’s £133.5m). The company stated at that time that Q4 had started better than Q3 and, based on the 7% full year growth, we estimate c£126m for Q4.

The importance of (always lumpy) quarterly trading updates remains very much secondary to the final outcome of the FCA’s review of the UK leveraged trading market. Having initially indicated an expected final conclusion by ‘late spring’, the most recent update from the FCA was in April with the publication of its 2017 Mission Statement. This stated that the Policy Statement will be ‘later this year’, opening up the possibility of it falling into calendar H2, and an effective implementation date likely to be a few months after that.

KS11:42am

China’s sovereign wealth fund is in late-stage negotiations to acquire Logicor from its private equity owner Blackstone, in a deal that would value the London-based warehouse property group at more than €12bn including debt.

China Investment Corporation and Blackstone could announce an agreement for the European-focused company as early as this week, according to people briefed on the discussions, who cautioned that the timing could still slip.

If agreed, it would rank as the second-largest European real estate transaction on record and the fourth-largest international Chinese takeover to date.

11:44 am
IK11:44am

The thesis behind investments in businesses like Logicor is that ecommerce companies such as Amazon and traditional retailers with growing web operations are dependent on storage and logistics facilities near major cities.
Logicor consists of 630 properties across Europe, representing a total of 13m square metres of warehouse space.
A takeover by CIC would rank as the second-largest European real estate transaction on record and the fourth-largest international Chinese takeover to date.

IK11:44am

More interestingly, the deal would be by far the largest-ever by the Chinese wealth fund. Dealmakers who have worked with CIC in the past told DD they were completely surprised to see the Chinese spending this sort of money without a JV or partner. A couple even expressed concerns that they may not be prepared to handle such a big venture on their own.

(@Residual: something like that probably. court reporting has all kinds of pitfalls)

IK11:48am

HICP inflation declined to +0.9% in May (Barclays: +1.0%, consensus: +1.1%), falling from 1.4% printed in April.
Details released by the INSEE statistics office at CPI level show that the decline was largely due to volatile components.
Food, and in particular fresh food products, along with energy inflation were particularly weak, falling to +0.4% and 5.4% y/y from +0.7% and +9.3% in April.
At the core level, however, there were no signs of improvement. Both services (+1.0%) and manufactured goods prices (-0.7%) were unchanged (y/y) compared to April.
All in all, today’s data for France reinforces our below consensus forecast for the euro area (to be released at 10:00 London time). We forecast headline HICP inflation to ease to +1.4%

Big banks are throttling back from the $1.2tn US car loan market, fearing that consumers have taken on more debt than they can handle. Lenders piled into the sector in the years after the financial crisis, as low defaults and an improving economy encouraged them to focus on a market that performed relatively well as mortgages soured. Total loans across the industry rose to $1.17tn at the end of the first quarter, according to the New York Federal Reserve, up almost 70 per cent from a trough in 2010.
